newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ireland's unions vote to accept new wage deal.
newsitem.headline: Ireland's unions vote to accept new wage deal.

text.p: Ireland's trade union movement voted on Thursday to accept the latest national wage agreement, a key element in Ireland's economic success in recent years.

Delegates at a special conference of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions (ICTU), the umbrella body representing all of Ireland's unions, voted by a margin of 83 votes to accept the new agreement, known as Partnership 2000.
There were 217 votes for the agreement and 134 against.
A consensus approach by government, employers and unions to the management of the economy, known as social partership, has been a cornerstone of Irish economic success in recent years.

This approach, which includes centralised pay agreements, has kept a lid on wage inflation and industrial unrest, allowing Ireland to enjoy the fastest-growing economy in the European Union while maintaining a comfortably low inflation rate.
Union ratification of Partnership 2000, the fourth agreement of its kind, was widely expected after a ballot by Ireland's largest union, SIPTU, approved it on Wednesday.
Irish employers have also endorsed the deal.

The Irish Business and Employers' Confederation (IBEC), which represents 5,000 employers, approved the agreement on Wednesday, saying it gave reasonable pay increases while protecting the competitiveness of industry.
Partnership 2000 allows for wage rises of 9.25 percent over a three-year period and promises tax reductions of 1.0 billion punts ($1.6 billion) over the life of the accord.
The programme also sets targets for the public finances, aiming for a general government deficit of not more than 1.5 percent of GDP and a debt/GDP ratio of 70 percent by 1999.
Analysts had been concerned that if the agreement were rejected, it could put upward pressure on Irish inflation.
Acceptance of the new deal effectively caps wage inflation at 2.5 percent this year and serves to limit upward pressure on consumer price inflation, they said.

"The agreement on Partnership 2000 means that the kind of social and economic solidarity, which has been one of the linchpins of our recent economic success, is maintained," the Irish Times said in its Thursday editorial.
The alternative - a return to free collective bargaining with..."leapfrogging claims" as various groups of workers press competing demands - is almost unthinkable." ($1=.6257 Punt)
